'Disulfur dichloride' is the chemical compound with the formula
S 2Cl 2 Holleman, A. F.; Wiberg, E. "Inorganic
Chemistry" Academic Press: San Diego, 2001. ISBN 0-12-352651-
5. R. J. Cremlyn âAn Introduction to Organosulfur
Chemistryâ John Wiley and Sons: Chichester (1996). ISBN 0-471-95512-4

. Some alternative names for this compound are sulfur monochloride (the name
  implied by its empirical formula, SCl), disulphur dichloride (British English
  Spelling) and sulphur monochloride (British English Spelling).
  S 2Cl 2 has the structure implied by the formula Cl-S-S-
  Cl, wherein the angle between the Cl a-S-S and S-S-Cl b
  planes is 90Â°. This structure is referred to as gauche, and is akin to that
  for H 2O 2. A different isomer of
  S 2Cl 2 is S=SCl 2; this isomer forms
  transiently when S 2Cl 2 is exposed to UV-radiation (see
  thiosulfoxides).
